#Help I have two lib modules both use common classes which is in a third module (common). What is the best way to set some properties in both libs using common module class ? for ex: API key, Log levels etc etc
right now I am using Static instance variables in common class, and using getters from other two libs. However I don’t think this approach is right.

<@U04TK850N>: No I dont need anything instead. Ok, let me give you a bit more info. I have added an extra toolbar in one of the fragments, just to show a searchbar, and i have kept the searchbar open, but it has this back button beside it,  thats what i got to get rid of
> right now I am using Static instance variables in common class
How do you do this?
Common.setCommonProperty(true); Then from other modules Common.getCommonProperty();
And these properties are set from app using either of the lib modules. Common is internal dependency to the both lib mobules.
Or am I overthinking ?
<@U055JANKU>: Yes

text: <@U0L71T98B|joseearce> pinned a message to this channel.

attachments.fallback:
[February 3rd, 2016 4:36 PM] eddie.ringle: so your setup process for Android repos is then:

1. Clone code styles repo
2. Run `./install.sh` in code styles repo
3. Clone app repo
4. Open app in Android Studio
5. AS Preferences -> Editor -> Code Style -> Choose proper scheme
6. Apply and get coding
attachments.text:
so your setup process for Android repos is then:

1. Clone code styles repo
2. Run `./install.sh` in code styles repo
3. Clone app repo
4. Open app in Android Studio
5. AS Preferences -> Editor -> Code Style -> Choose proper scheme
6. Apply and get coding

text: WTF, left as an exercise, does someone have a gist with the answer?
iunno why my message was pinned, but okay ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
how can I scroll to the bottom of a recycler view and add like a padding to it?

<@U0KTPB91V>: I don't think that was possible in the past. But there was something about about the RecyclerView relating to its size (can't remember it, not too long ago though) that should allow for something like that
(Or was very hard to do in the past)
<@U0KTPB91V>: but you can add padding to the last element?
you got an idea for me ?
<@U061HDV96>: not sure, I try linear layout `smooth scroll with offset` method but not luck
Well the way RecyclerViews work is kind of weird, something changed with it lately. You should look it up
I know for sure you could just add a blank view to the end of your RecyclerView, but that's a bit hack-y imo and might require you to create another ViewHolder type and stuff
<@U0LA8E1NK|arthur-it> has joined the channel
you can do an item decorator and apply a margin to the last element
(in reference to the padding at the end)
outside of that I think your options are the blank view <@U0546QERR> mentioned or some custom LayoutManager that handles the case for you
<@U0LAC855G|build3r> has joined the channel
<@U0LA609EY|ypiruzyan> has joined the channel
<@U0B9AAKQF> Hi have the exact problem, I have a ToolBar and Recyler View. The last item of the RecylerView is cutoff by the height of the ToolBar. It even affects the Floating Button.
the toolbar is on the bottom of the screen?
screenshot?
Looks like the the whole view is pushed down by the ToolBar
yeah, kinda not following that one
open in DDMS or something and confirm the RecyclerView stops at the bottom of the screen?
No, view is pushed down the screen by the ToolBar
screenshot would be helpful
<@U0LACDY7K|marika.devan> has joined the channel

<@U0LAC855G|build3r> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/build3r/F0LAE52TS/screenshot_2016-02-05-01-03-20.png|Here you go, the last time is cut which is same as the height of the ToolBar>

text: BTW thats the maximum scroll.
what type of layout is the parent

I’d be concerned that your RecyclerView is off the bottom of the screen.  Using an item decorator trick is handy if you are doing something dynamic behind the list but in your case the RecyclerView looks like it shoudl always anchor at the bottom of the screen
It's basically a coordinator layout having the ToolBar and a scroll view. The scroll view contains the RecylerView and rest of the elements.
There a reason the RecyclerView can’t hold the elements that you put in the scrollview?
<@U0B9AAKQF> can you elaborate on you solution. I'm not fully aware of Item Decorators
seems odd to nest that
<@U0LAC855G>: check out <http://developer.android.com/reference/android/support/v7/widget/RecyclerView.ItemDecoration.html>
also: I don’t think its the solution you are looking for in this particular case
It's basically to allow user to scroll out side the RecylerView to collapse the tool bar so that he can have detailed look a the RecylerView elements.

<@U0B9AAKQF> I actually wanted the ToolBar to collapse when the user stared to scroll the RecylerView but its was kind of not possible to do this having few more elements in between the RecylerView and ToolBar.
what stopping you from putting those elements into the RecyclerView?  they handle different types pretty well
There are lot of reasons which stopped me from doing it.
One was that I wanted to keep static things separate from dynamic ones.
<@U0LAFUDA6|gmanfunkflex5000> has joined the channel
<@U0B9AAKQF>: let’s say I have a recycler view, on top of it, another view, how can I scroll to the top of the other view?, that’s why I was asking about the margin at bottom
:disappointed:
Is it a good pattern to extract listeners (TextWatchers, FocusChangeListener … on EditText for example) into their own file and pass them the activity as an injected dependency?
My app is pretty simple but already the Activity class is getting out of hand ...
i'd probably just subclass the view itself and add that stuff
that would not allow me to call methods in the activity?
well, no
but i'm guessing you're accessing those methods from the listener
say some input has a listener attached that has to do something depending on another inputs value
so if you just extract the listener you're running into the same problem
yeah
thats why I pass the activiy instance in the listeners ctor
and promote a method to public in the activity
doesn’t feel that great, that’s why I ask
but keeping all those listeners as anonymous/inner classes is shitty as well :smile:
i think they're equivalent implementations, inner classes have an implicit reference to the outer (activity) which enables you to call those methods
so whatever looks nicer to you/your team i guess :stuck_out_tongue:
I feel like I’m missing a well known pattern in Android land as a newb :smile:
I’ve had some luck using the same listener for a bunch of views and determining what to do based on the id of the view passed to the listener
you end up with a big switch statement but your actual handler methods are onUserClickedSomethingICareAbout() instead of anonymous inner classes
ah yeah, you can get the activity to implement the listener itself, then attach the activity as the listener
on your view
yeah <@U0546QERR>, missed that part in my explanation
but I hate having any sort of complex code in an anonymous inner class… too easy to miss it when scanning through to figure out what is going on
Yeah what I like about extracting the listeners is that I can test some of them in pure junit
havent had the best of luck with roboelectric so far
honestly we’ve switched to a passive view MVP and all the business logic is in the presenter which is pure java
so you can junit that and have your click handlers either call methods on the presenter
most of my listeners are just `mPresenter.onThisHappened()`
yup
trying to find some good links on MVP that I followed when we were trying to figure this out
I was gonna ask, any blog posts you recommend on reading up on mvp?
the fragmented podcast had a great episode on it a while back
<http://fragmentedpodcast.com/episodes/11/>
the links on the blog page for the episode had some great info
my only mark against it is testing the presenter is kinda awkward if you are doing anything asynchronously in the presenter layer
since the output of the presenter is method calls on your view you have to create a fake view and record the calls to verify your presenter did what you were expecting
so the test code is complicated but its nice to be able to test the meat of your app in a junit

<@U0B9AAKQF>: >presenter is kinda awkward if you are doing anything asynchronously in the presenter layer
what kind of async stuff do you do in presenter?
we have a weather section and a list of locations.  The locations are immediately accessible but the weather conditions for the locations aren’t
so we load the list of locations immediately and the load the conditions as we get a response from our weather service
there are bunch of other layers in there too, but the presenter has to request the weather and update when the response comes back
testing it sucked, but it works pretty well once it was all together
well that shouldn’t be in the presenter, that should be in a data layer
you can mock the data layer
and no problems for testing
wouldn’t that require the data layer to keep a static copy of the last weather requested?
and your data layer woudl need to download the weather as part of an initialization step before you could open that part of the app?
you shouldn't be making network requests in tests
that's all i know lol

your presenter does the request -> data layer downloads -> calls presenter back
in test your presenter does the request -> fake data layer provides data -> calls presenter back
you can even use a mockwebserver
agreed, we have a data layer and we can mock the network easily
we are also using Rx and the data layer is handing an observable back
so even if its a mock and the response is immediate we have to treat the observable as if it can’t return immediately
I’m not 100% sure I  like where we ended up with on it but it did work pretty well
open to suggestions if there is a better way to do it
tbh for unit tests, there is no need for that  but you can always set a delay on the mock server

Regardless of where you are getting the data, if the presenter needs to request information the app can’t possibly have before the request you are going to end up with a view.updateData() call that happens at some point in the future after the presenter.requestData() completes  (callbacks or Rx).  Testing that behavior is what sucked for me
okay, I totally lost you :joy:
oh I think I get you
how could the app have the data before the request?
if its static data or something you need to make the app run at all you can make getting the data part of the app initialization
still don’t see problem testing with data coming before or after request
oh well, probably some miscommunication is happening here :smile:
yeah, I :heart: slack but it can be kinda tough to talk through some times
<https://github.com/antoniolg/androidmvp/blob/master/app/src/main/java/com/antonioleiva/mvpexample/app/main/MainActivity.java#L49>
so thats what they are doing in this mvp example as well
passing the activity in the ctor and having some public methods on it to update the ui
<@U0K65E0NB>: not passing the activity, passing whatever object it is that implements view. it could be a POJO for all you know
he's passing MainView
yeah abstracted through an interface
basically passing the activity, it's just abstracted into an interface
i think that's a good example to follow
in fact the naming convention is identical to mine
lol
MainView, MainPresenterImpl are both classes i have
oh, the asynchronous work is pulled into an interactor
yep add some dagger to that and it’s mostly what I’ve been doing for the last 2 years
and tbh I always have a fear inside me that I’m doing something dumb
so you mock the interactor and your presenter can be guaranteed to call back immediately?
yep
like you can literally have your interactor mock impl return a json string if you want
this times 3 is what my `onCreate` now looks like
<@U0548MM6B>:  do you use RxJava at all?
yep
mostly for interactors
are your interactors Junit testable?
using retrofit 2 for networking, return observables
I always wonder about AndroidSchedulers.mainThread() and who gets to know about it
does retrofit do a subscribeOn or does it just use OkHttp’s dispatcher to get the network io off of the main thread?
you have to call subscribeOn yourself
yea problem is that AndroidSchedulers.mainThread uses androids Handler
yup, it isn’t an async call, makes sense tho innit, since it happens when you subscribe
i wonder if they fixed the call.cancel() on the main thread thing
in beta4
it’s fixed in the latest okhttp release
which should be in beta4 :smile:
i'll try it out in a bit
yeah it’s done
they use 3.0.1
tho must say I missed out on beta4 I’m still on 3
jake just tweeted it this morning i think
i haven't updated yet either
aaah :smile:
that’s why
I need to get smarter. working on canary AS, using retrofit 2 beta in prod, even used dagger 2 alpha in production….
now I got lost where I was heading
anyways <@U0B9AAKQF> you can just inject the scheduler you want
true… the injection would save us once we start using dagger2
you can do it without a framework, pass it through the constructor for the interactor and you’ve basically got DI

so instead of CoolInteractor(mockServiceOrWhatever) you can call CoolInteractor(mockServiceOrWhatever, TotallyNotAndroidSchedlr) and in the app CoolInteractor(mockServiceOrWhatever, AndroidSchedulers)
which I did but it felt odd
eh it’s not odd until you can’t even :stuck_out_tongue:
you can change schedulers in test without passing them in
if you want
override them with immediate?
yeah you can
if you are feeling inclined
how do you do it?
whatever you do will be promoted as best practice anyways :stuck_out_tongue:
I like that <@U0548MM6B> “until you can’t even"
deep inside I’m a basic white girl :joy:
`RxJavaPlugins.getInstance().registerSchedulersHook(`
takes a class where you can override the io scheduler, new thread scheduler or computation scheduler
just return Schedulers.immediate()
inb4 <@U091EBYSU> says to never do that
that’s what I meant by overriding them with immediate

probably taking a sip from bottle of vodka here and there

:open_mouth: :open_mouth: :open_mouth: :open_mouth:

<@U0LATL928|lordlobo> has joined the channel
<@U0LB0K831|pencan94> has joined the channel
Poll time: Whose responsibility is it to set subscribeOn for an Observable? The provider or the consumer?
<@U060Q7J2Y> <@U091EBYSU> You two were discussing RxJava earlier. Any opinions?
i set it from the provider... provider should know if the observable needs to be on a different thread or not
plus then all of that logic is in the same class
Consumer
we’ve so much pain with that
<@U0546QERR>: but remember that you can’t override subscribeOn if it’s set earlier up the chain
basically, if you want to test your code, then you’ll set it on consumer side
because you won’t be able to “override” already set `subscribeOn` and the only thing you’ll be able to do is to change schedulers
right

We've just pushed Android Studio 2.0 Beta 2 to the canary channel.This fixes an Instant Run related bug we discovered right after rolling beta 1 out. Please give beta 2 a try; we believe we've fixed several critical issues that have prevented builds from working for a number of users in earlier previews:Performance regression: Many users reported that the initial build in 2.0 was much slower than in 1.5. Turns out this was related to the way we packaged all dependencies into a single dex...

text: "Dagger2 and other annotation-processor based libraries and plugins: In 2.x we've been using the new "incremental Java compilation" feature in Gradle, but this feature does not work well with annotation processor. In beta2, we automatically turn off incremental compilation if a project appears to be using annotation processors through the "android-apt" plugin. Manually wired processors will still fail"

text: set it on the theme of the activity?
<@U0JBN2DV2>: I think it’s the amount of time allotted for processing sound
Bigger means the process will demand less resource on the system
too big you will notice lag
smaller means the process will demand more resource on the system
its only for sounds ? not for files like ? pdf txt zip etc
Oh I thought you are asking about sound recording
so we need `bufferSize` in every type of files ? right ?
If you stream it yes
After saw your code, I’ll say yes
here am trying to convert a file into bytearray
and its working fine i just wondered what this `bufferSize` thing is
The size of your buffer :wink:
:flushed: the size is good or bad ? :sweat_smile:
please just use Okio
and save yourself some headache with that ^
<@U060Q7J2Y>:  thats for me ? :point_up_2:

Pretty sure you should pick your buffer size smaller than the file system block size. But that is probably less relevant on flash memory than it was on hard disks. There reading one block in full or reading one block and one byte would make a difference
